title: Rhyme in two languages?
content:
I was browsing through my Flander and Swan music recently and I came across their Mozart tribute 'Eine kleine Nactmusik.' and it got me thinking; can you rhyme in two languages without altering the meaning that much?

I'm willing to give it a try with Mozart tribute: [Sung to the tune of Mozarts 'Eine kleine Nachtmusik of course.]

In English:

Just a little music in the night,
makes me want to hold my baby tight.
Mr Mozart, play that melody.
Just a little night music for me.

Auf Deutsh:

Eine kleine Musik in der Nacht
lt mich meine Freundin halten fest.
Herr Mozart, spielen die Melodie.
Eine kleine Nachtmusik fr Sie.


I know there are some errors, I'm not a languages scholar.


A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/lind.jpg[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

content:

title: Re: Rhyme in two languages?
content:
I wish to discuss;

the difficulties of translation, especially when translating rhyming verse and its many colloquialisims and slangs.

How english pop songs sound in Germany.

Mozart.

title: hum
content:
Once, for rediculous amounts of extra credit, I wrote limericks in Spanish for my Spanish class. Unfortunately for me, I conjugated some of the verbs incorrectly, so the rhymes weren't all that hot... but I tried so hard I got most of the extra credit anyway. :-)

Ultimately, they were very simple rhymes--along the lines of Dr. Seuss. :-P Nothing to write home about, but hey--I got an A!

title: Re: hum
content:
Neato XKy...

BTW - Lots of Latin Hymns ryme as well as their english counterpaerts, but are changed slightly.

Adoro te Devote, in latin, has no chorus, but it's English counterpart, Humbly we Adore Thee, does.
